p.hi: Thursday, August 15
th

Before getting up I read aloud to Ella Cowper's "Expostulation". It would be difficult to improve upon the following as a description of our "Ritualists": it is by the Poet himself applied generally, though suggested by the religious decay of ancient Israel: –
Then Ceremony leads her bigots forth,
Prepar'd to flight for shadows of no worth;
While truths, on which eternal things depends,
Find not, or hardly find, a single friend:
As soldiers watch the signal of command,
They learn to bow, to kneel, to sit, to stand;
Happy to fill religion's vacant place,
With hollow form, and gesture, and grimace.
It is in this poem that the famous denunciation of the Test Act occurs. It follows a remarkable description of the "nabob's" career: The poet addresses Britain thus unflatteringly: –
Hast thou, though suckled at fair Freedom's breast,
Exported slavery to the conquer'd east?
Pull'd down the tyrants India served with dread,
And raised thyself a greater, in their stead?
Gone thither arm'd and hungry, return'd full,
Fed from the richest veins of the Mogul,
A despot big with power obtained by wealth,
And that obtained by rapine and by stealth?
With Asiatic vices stored thy mind,
But left their virtues and thine own behind?
And, having truck'd thy soul, brought home the fee,
To tempt the poor to sell himself to thee?
[ All this might be applied not unfairly to our Rand millionaires, and rubber speculators, who have shone in Park Lane of late years. ]
Hast thou by statute shoved from its design
The Saviour's Feast, his own bless'd bread and wine,
And made the symbols of atoning grace
An office–key, a picklock to a place,
That infidels may prove their title good
By an oath dipp'd in sacramental blood?
A blot that will be still a blot, in spite
Of all that brave apologists may write:
And though a bishop toil to cleanse the stains,
He wipes and scours the silver cup in vain.
[The bishop presumably was the braggart, carnal, paradoxical Warburton who represented the Test Act as the essential feature of Establishment.]

In 1785 Cooper published "Tirocinium; or a Review of Schools", in which he drew a dark picture of the public schools of the time, & denounced them as morally contaminating and intellectually sterilizing. It is gloomily suggestive that precisely the same picture has recently been drawn by
Aleck Waugh
, a Sherborne boy, in "
The Loom of Youth
". Probably in 1917 as in 1785 there was exaggeration, but, as probably, the broad impression conveyed is not unjust.
